Andean Initiative, Center for Latin American and Caribbean Studies (CLACS) | NYU                           NEW YORK UNIVERSITY       ARTS AND SCIENCE       COLLEGE OF ARTS AND SCIENCE       GRADUATE SCHOOL OF ARTS AND SCIENCE                                                                                                             About Us       People       Undergraduate       Graduate Program       Faculty Resources       Alumni Network       Caribbean Initiative       Andean Initiative       Quechua Language       K-12 Outreach       Events               Home > Andean Initiative     Andean Initiative   The CLACS-NYC Andean Institute was launched in 2009 as a material and virtual resource to promote regional training and outreach related to the peoples and countries of the Andean region. This region follows the Andes mountain chain from Colombia through Ecuador, Peru, and Bolivia, to Chile and NW Argentina. The Institute draws upon the CLACS commitment to Quechua language training , the depth of expertise on the region among CLACS Affiliated Faculty at NYU, and the large number of Andeanists at other NYC-area institutions, as well as the presence of a vibrant Andeanist and Andean community around the city.  The Andean Institute brings together faculty, students, research, academic debate, and outreach resources. It also hosts colloquia, conferences, and Andean-related events , as well as promotes courses about the Andes. The Institute is proud to offer Quechua language courses , and also sponsors a monthly Quechua language conversation night which is open to the public.  Through this website, the Institute fosters a virtual community for the diffusion of new research, providing a space for dynamic dialogue. We are proud that the Andean Institute connects communities within the NYC area, and serves as a bridge between the NYC region and Andean countries. Andean Initiative, Center for Latin American and Caribbean Studies (CLACS) | NYU                           NEW YORK UNIVERSITY       ARTS AND SCIENCE       COLLEGE OF ARTS AND SCIENCE       GRADUATE SCHOOL OF ARTS AND SCIENCE                                                                                                             About Us       People       Undergraduate       Graduate Program       Faculty Resources       Alumni Network       Caribbean Initiative       Andean Initiative       Quechua Language       K-12 Outreach       Events               Home > Andean Initiative     Andean Initiative   The CLACS-NYC Andean Institute was launched in 2009 as a material and virtual resource to promote regional training and outreach related to the peoples and countries of the Andean region. This region follows the Andes mountain chain from Colombia through Ecuador, Peru, and Bolivia, to Chile and NW Argentina. The Institute draws upon the CLACS commitment to Quechua language training , the depth of expertise on the region among CLACS Affiliated Faculty at NYU, and the large number of Andeanists at other NYC-area institutions, as well as the presence of a vibrant Andeanist and Andean community around the city.  The Andean Institute brings together faculty, students, research, academic debate, and outreach resources. It also hosts colloquia, conferences, and Andean-related events , as well as promotes courses about the Andes. The Institute is proud to offer Quechua language courses , and also sponsors a monthly Quechua language conversation night which is open to the public.  Through this website, the Institute fosters a virtual community for the diffusion of new research, providing a space for dynamic dialogue. We are proud that the Andean Institute connects communities within the NYC area, and serves as a bridge between the NYC region and Andean countries. Indigenous Resistance in the Andes | CLACS | NYU                               NEW YORK UNIVERSITY       ARTS AND SCIENCE       COLLEGE OF ARTS AND SCIENCE       GRADUATE SCHOOL OF ARTS AND SCIENCE                           Center for Latin American and Caribbean Studies                            Back to Events         Printer Friendly       A Conversation: Indigenous Resistance Against Extractivism in the Andes           Carlos Perez Guartambel and Manuela Lavinas Picq    ,     Location: King Juan Carlos I of Spain Center (KJCC) Room 404W, 53 Washington Square South, New York University, New York NY 10012 (map)   CLACS, NACLA, and the Quechua Study at NYU present a conversation between Carlos Perez Guartambel and Manuela Lavinas Picq, translated by Antonia Carcelén Estrada.    Carlos Perez Guartambel (President of ECUARUNARI) is an originary Kichwa Kañari, lawyer, who taught at the University of Cuenca and the Politécnica Salesiana University. Among the many books he has published are: Justicia indígena , Agua u Oro, Introducción al Derecho Parlamentario, La Asamblea Constituyente en el Ecuador, Las consultas comunitarias en el Ecuador . He is currently the President of Ecuarunari , the Indigenous organization from the Ecuadorian highlands with a strong legay of political mobilization. Before, he presided the Federation of Indigenous and Peasant Organizations of Azuay and the Union of Community Water Systems in Azuay, a province in the south of Ecuador. He also was the Director of the Abya Yala Center for Mediation, and a Council Member for the City of Cuenca. He was criminalized for defending water and illegally arrested five times (he fulfilled his sentence in 2013). Manuela Lavinas Picq is Professor of International Relations at Universidad San Francisco de Quito, Ecuador. Her research bridges international relations and comparative politics to tackle issues of gender, ethnicity, and stateness in Latin America. She has been a Junior Scholar for the Study of Democracy at the Woodrow Wilson Center and a Loewenstein Fellow at Amherst College. She is currently finishing a book project analyzing how indigenous women impact world politics in Ecuador. In 2013-2014, she is a Member at the Institute for Advanced Study working on a project called “Cosmopolitan Amazons: Disentangling Modernity from the State.” She has published in venues such as the Journal of Latin American Politics and Society and International Political Science Review , and is a regular opinion contributor to Al Jazeera English.    Antonia Carcelén Estrada is a Visiting Lecturer in the Department of Latin American and Latino Studies at the College of the Holy Cross. Her research focuses on postcolonial literature, colonial and contemporary Latin America, Siglo de Oro literature, translation studies, philosophy, cultural studies, art history, anthropology, and oral literature.    ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~    Carlos Perez Guartambel (Presidente de la ECUARUNARI) es indígena Kichwa Kañari, abogado, fue docente de la Universidad de Cuenca y Politécnica Salesiana y tiene varios libros publicados: Justicia indígena , Agua u Oro, Introducción al Derecho Parlamentario, La Asamblea Constituyente en el Ecuador, Las consultas comunitarias en el Ecuador , entre otros. Actualmente es Presidente de la Ecuarunari y antes fue Presidente de la Federación de Organizaciones Indígenas y Campesinas del Azuay y de la Unión de Sistemas Comunitarios de Agua del Azuay. También fue Director del Centro de Mediación Abya Yala, Concejal de la Ciudad de Cuenca. Fue criminalizado por defender el agua con 5 detenciones ilegales, acusado de terrorismo altruista (cumplió su sentencia en 2013).                         The event is free and open to the public.
